name: Anemia
contents:
Anaemia and blood transfusion both independent risk factors for:

  • Increase morbidity and mortality
  • Increase length of stay
  • Increased complications such as MI, infections

NICE Quality Standard on blood transfusion 2016

Implementation of Perioperative Medicine


A condition in which there is a deficiency of red blood cells, or of haemoglobin, resulting in pallor or weakness

Normal ranges in adults according to WHO:

  • Men: 130 – 170 g/L
  • Women: 120 – 150 g/L

Prevalence increases with age, gender and geography


International consensus for surgical patients is 130g/L for both sexes

Compared with men, women have:

  • lower circulating blood volumes
  • reduced red cell mass
  • Comparable volumes of blood loss
  • Higher rates of transfusion
contents2:
• Iron deficiency anaemia
  • 2-5% prevalence in adult men and post-menopausal women
  • Up to 30% of surgical population
  • Sideroblastic anaemia
  • Congenital or acquired
  • Anaemia of chronic inflammation
  • Thalassaemia


Causes of IDA- see below
contents3:
Iron deficiency;:

  • Ferritin-highly sensitive
  • <30 micrograms/L =absolute IDA
  • 30-100 micrograms/L = may still be IDA
  • Acute phase reactant, so spuriously high in the presence of inflammation
  • Also spuriously low in 2nd and 3rd trimester of pregnancy
  • Transferrin saturation <20%


Causes of IDA:

  • Diet-most common nutritional deficiency in the world
  • Gastrointestinal blood loss
  • Ulceration
  • Diverticulitis
  • GI malignancy
  • Angiodysplasia
  • Inflammatory bowel disease
  • Obstetric / Gynaecological causes
  • Menstruation
  • Pregnancy
question4: Causes of normocytic anemia and macrocytic anemia
contents4:
Normocytic anemia

  • Chronic kidney disease
  • Sickle cell disease
  • Anaemia of chronic inflammation
  •  B6 (pyridoxine) deficiency
  •  B2 (riboflavin) deficiency
  • Aplastic anaemia
  • Hypothyroid
  • Recent blood loss
  • Mixture of macro- and microcytic anaemia


Macrocytic

  • B12 deficiency
  • Folate deficiency
  • Alcohol excess
  • Drugs eg metformin, phenytoin, chemotherapy, 
  • Myelodysplasia
question5: Causes of anemia in the surgical population, Initial Ix,
contents5:
• Up to 30% preoperatively
  • Up to 90% having major surgery postoperatively
  • Most common causes:
  • Iron deficiency
  • Acute blood loss


Initial investigations.

  • Haematinics 
  • Ferritin
  • Transferrin saturation
  • B12/Folate
  •  Blood film
  • Particularly in the extremes of anaemias, and suspicion of dysplasia
  •  Haemoglobinopathy screen
  • Particularly in younger patients, ethnicities
  • Urea and electrolytes
  • LFTS
  • CRP
  • Consider upper and lower GI investigations in patients as 2WW with certain signs and symptoms:
  • Have symptoms of dyspepsia
  • Men (any age) with Hb < 110 g/dL
  • Women (non-menstruating) with Hb < 105 g/dL
  • All patients > age 75

Further Ix:

  • In addition (particularly for patients over 75):
  • Myeloma screen
  • Immunoglobulin profile
  • Serum and urine electrophoresis
  • Coeliac screen
